masterFinding.verificationInstructions:
Verification Instructions:


Look for buckets that have names such as "NetSPI_merger_with_big_company". These names are unique across all s3 buckets, so others will get an error if they try to register it, revealing that this bucket exists and is probably realistically named. The easiest way to detect this is by always checking the subdomain when the application loads files from S3 buckets.

Reporting Requirements:


Screenshot the name of the bucket. Redact if extremely sensitive and set up a phone call to provide the name.
masterFinding.remediationInstructions: Change the name of the S3 bucket and do not use sensitive information as the name of future buckets.
masterFinding.name: AWS - S3 - Bucket Name Information Disclosure
masterFinding.businessImpact: Even if the contents of the bucket are properly secured and not publicly accessible, the S3 bucket name itself containing sensitive information may result in disclosure of information that is not intended to be publicly disclosed.
masterFinding.description: AWS Simple Storage Service (S3) allows users to register a subdomain under the s3.amazonaws.com subdomain. Because of this, all S3 buckets must have unique names across the entire AWS service. Registering buckets with descriptive and sensitive names allows other users to see that domain has already been registered.
